Don't expect to see Wal-Mart tellers and ATMs any time soon, but the nation's largest retailer has gone to regulators seeking authority to open a state-chartered bank.
By doing that, Wal-Mart says it could process the hundreds of millions of electronic payments it handles every year.
But as NPR's Jack Speer reports, giving Wal-Mart a toehold into banking is controversial.
When you're as big as Wal-Mart, almost everything you do is viewed with suspicion, and that's true of the retailer's request to get into banking.
Jane Thompson is President of Wal-Mart's Financial Services Division, and at a hearing before the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, she sought to reassure regulators.
She said Wal-Mart has no plans to change its system where it leases space in more than a thousand of its stores to retail banks.
We have absolutely no plans to open bank branches.
In fact, as the retailer with the largest number of in-store banks in the U.S., Wal-Mart may be one of the most supportive corporations for independent banks anywhere.
But an unusual coalition of bankers, consumer groups, and unions converged at the two-day hearing, urging the FDIC not to approve Wal-Mart's request.
Terry Jorde chairs the Independent Community Bankers of America, and is president of a small community bank in Cando, North Dakota.

Allowing Wal-Mart to own a bank would irreversibly change the fundamental structure of the American financial system by allowing the world's largest corporation to violate our nation's long-standing policy against the mixing of banking and commerce.
And that opinion was echoed by most of the witnesses testifying at the hearing.

But those who follow banking point out that several large corporations--General Electric through its GE Capital Unit and Wal-Mart's rival Target--already have similar kinds of limited banking operations, raising the question why the FDIC is taking the unprecedented step of holding two separate hearings on Wal-Mart's request.
What they're doing is responding to the human cry.
That's banking expert Burt Ely.
He says Wal-Mart has had more ambitious goals for getting into banking in the past, but has scaled back this time.
Still, he's not sure the retailer will succeed.
Wal-Mart's been trying since 1999, and they keep coming back to the well, and people continue to oppose it, and really get quite emotional about it.
However, outside the FDIC hearing room in Arlington, Virginia, Wal-Mart spokesman Ray Bracy said allowing the retailer to get into banking, even on a limited basis, will benefit customers.
You know, Wal-Mart is known for its relentless attack on inefficiencies.
And what we're really trying to do is remove the third party, and if we do that, we can save money.
When we save money, what we do is we pass the savings on to consumers.
Federal regulators are not expected to rule on Wal-Mart's request right away.
After today's hearing wraps up, there will be another one later this month in Overland Park, Kansas.
The FDIC says it's received a record 1,900 comment letters on Wal-Mart's request--most want Wal-Mart to stay out of banking.
Jack Speer, NPR News.
